title: They call me Mister PHP
body:
Many of you may not know this, but in my last life - my corporate one - I was a bona fide script slinger. By day, a mild mannered content editor, but by night... I was a PHP GOD! You see, PHP and I are very good friends. A few years ago, PHP kneed me right in the junk, but I forgave PHP. Why? Because we're tight, that's why.

So I've been spending the last few days and nights banging out the Ub3r-1337 backend to the Moxie website. Not only will the functionality of the Moxie website be relying on my nimbley* coded functions, but I'm also using the same base structure to build a multi-dimensional, relational, quasi-bipedal P.O.S. (point of sale) system. I've mentioned the P.O.S. system before, but now that I'm in the thick of it, it's all I can think about. When I'm coding, I can't be bothered.

Nicole: Dan.. (waits for a response) I'm pregnant.
Dan: Uh huh.
Nicole: With a case of Ice Mountain bottled water.
Dan: Uh huh.
Nicole: And my water just broke.
Dan: Great.
Nicole: On your wireless router.
Dan: (like Darth Vadar) Nooooooooooooooooo!

The great thing about writing custom software for your own proprietary applications is that you always have tech support... 24/7. Unless, of course, I'm in the water closet, which would make the support drop to around 18/5. Even still, that's better than what you'll get with Macromedia (snicker snicker). Another nice "pro" of writing your own software is being able to make your variables as arcane as possible. I can't tell you how many $bjork variables are running this very blog. If I told you, you'd probably $crap all over the $toilet.

At this point, I realize I've alienated 98% of my audience, but for those of you who are still reading, hoping for some sense of closure, I hate to tell you that there's none to be found. Instead, here's a list of things I've built with PHP:

1. A program that tracks our recurring bills
2. An igloo
3. An application that renames all my MP3s
4. A box that protects me from thunderstorms

Ok, seriously... here's the lowdown. I'm in the midst of programming a complex set of applications that will run everything from ticket creation (via our cheap ink jet printer), transaction recording and reporting (ala P.O.S.), up-to-date movie listings, online ticket sales, and be completely accessible from my trusty home computer. I'm also trying to program an electronic cash drawer (via USB) to interface with my P.O.S. software (as per Justin's suggestion).

This one time, I was walking down the street and some dude came up to me and was like, "Hey, Dan! What's shakin'?" And I was like, "They call me MISTER PHP!"

On tomorrow's show: Dan is back with 24's Carlos Bernard and a new post that will probably be better than this one. Probably.

* nimbleyÂ© is not a real word, but from henceforth is a owned by this blog. Use it with care.
